On Sun, 24 Nov 2002, Bill de h=D3ra wrote:
> I like the /test/ expansion id=
ea, but... I can't be bothered typing
> this[1] in day in day out:

> [1] p=
ackage @package

IDEA does this for you automatically for any class.


> im=
port junit.framework.TestCase;
> import junit.framework.TestSuite;
> import=
 junit.textui.TestRunner;
> import java.util.*;
> import java.io.*;
> impor=
t com.propylon.test.UnitTestable;

IDEA takes care of all import statements=
 for you automatically too.


> /**
>   *
>   * @version $Revision: 1.1 $
>=
   * @author <a href=3D"mailto:bill.dehora@...">Bill de h=D3ra</a>=

>   */

This too.


> public class @Class
>    extends TestCase implements=
 UnitTestable

It types the "public class ClassName" for you; you have to t=
ype the rest.


> {
>
>    public @Class( String name )
>    {
>      super=
(name);
>    }

This constructor is no longer required for JUnit. I haven't=
 found any
disadvantage to not using this constructor; does anyone know of =
one?


>    public static void main(String[] args)
>    {
>      TestRunner=
.run(suite());
>    }

This isn't required with IDEA, because it can run an=
y TestCase you ask it
to even if there is no main() method.


>    public s=
tatic Test suite()
>    {
>      return new TestSuite(@...);
>    }=


I never override this method; I assume that it's not necessary (?).


>  =
  protected void setUp()
>    { }
>
>    protected void tearDown()
>    { }=


I don't use these methods too often, so I wouldn't put them in a template=
.
When I need them, I hit ctrl-O (for "override method") and IDEA shows me =
a
list of methods I can override, I pick one or more, and the code is
creat=
ed.

I am not usually fond of tools that write code for me magically (I thi=
nk
it could be done better a different way), but IDEA is well enough writte=
n
that I trust it to write my code.

Also, anything that IDEA can do, Eclip=
se can probably do too, and without
the hefty price tag.



Erik
